data_objects.name: chrome_surface_frame_id_to_first_display_id
data_objects.desc:
Links surface frames (`chrome_graphics_pipeline_surface_frame_steps`) to the
 the first display frame (`chrome_graphics_pipeline_display_frame_steps`) into
 which it was included. As an display frame usually aggregates frames from
 multiple surfaces, multiple `surface_frame_trace_id`s will correspond to one
 `display_trace_id`.
data_objects.summary_desc: Links surface frames (`chrome_graphics_pipeline_surface_frame_steps`) to the  the first display frame (`chrome_graphics_pipeline_display_frame_steps`) into  which it was included

cols.name: surface_frame_trace_id
cols.desc: Id of the graphics pipeline, pre-surface aggregation.

cols.name: display_trace_id
cols.desc: Id of the graphics pipeline, post-surface aggregation.

data_objects.name: chrome_graphics_pipeline_inputs_to_surface_frames
data_objects.desc:
Links inputs (`chrome_input_pipeline_steps.latency_id`) to the surface frame
 (`chrome_graphics_pipeline_surface_frame_steps`) to which they correspond.
 In other words, in general, multiple `latency_id`s will correspond to one
 `surface_frame_trace_id`.
data_objects.summary_desc: Links inputs (`chrome_input_pipeline_steps.latency_id`) to the surface frame  (`chrome_graphics_pipeline_surface_frame_steps`) to which they correspond

cols.name: latency_id
cols.desc: Id corresponding to the input pipeline.

cols.name: surface_frame_trace_id
cols.desc: Id of the graphics pipeline, post-surface aggregation.

modules.data_check_sql: SELECT EXISTS(SELECT 1 FROM slice WHERE name = 'Graphics.Pipeline' LIMIT 1) AS has_data

data_objects.name: chrome_web_content_interactions
data_objects.desc:
Chrome web content interactions (InteractionToFirstPaint), including
 associated high-level metrics and properties.

 Multiple events may occur for the same interaction; each row in this table
 represents the primary (longest) event for the interaction.

 Web content interactions are discrete, as opposed to sustained (e.g.
 scrolling); and only occur with the web content itself, as opposed to other
 parts of Chrome (e.g. omnibox). Interaction events include taps, clicks,
 keyboard input (typing), and drags.
data_objects.summary_desc: Chrome web content interactions (InteractionToFirstPaint), including  associated high-level metrics and properties

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Unique id for this interaction.

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: Start timestamp of the event. Because multiple events may occur for the same interaction, this is the start timestamp of the longest event.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: Duration of the event. Because multiple events may occur for the same interaction, this is the duration of the longest event.

cols.name: interaction_type
cols.desc: The interaction type.

cols.name: total_duration_ms
cols.desc: The total duration of all events that occurred for the same interaction.

cols.name: renderer_upid
cols.desc: The process id this event occurred on.

cols.name: description
cols.desc: A description of the EventLatency stage.

Augmented slices for Speedometer measurements.
 These are the intervals of time Speedometer uses to compute the final score.
 There are two intervals that are measured for every test: sync and async
 sync is the time between the start and sync-end marks, async is the time
 between the sync-end and async-end marks.
data_objects.summary_desc: Augmented slices for Speedometer measurements

data_objects.name: chrome_speedometer_2_1_iteration
data_objects.desc:
Slice that covers one Speedometer iteration.
 This slice is actually estimated as a default Speedometer run will not emit
 marks to cover this interval. The metrics associated are the same ones
 Speedometer would output, but note we use ns precision (Speedometer uses
 ~100us) so the actual values might differ a bit. Also note Speedometer
 returns the values in ms these here and in ns.

cols.name: score

Returns hardware class of the device, often use to find device brand

data_objects.name: chrome_vsync_intervals
data_objects.desc:
A simple table that checks the time between VSync (this can be used to
 determine if we're refreshing at 90 FPS or 60 FPS).

 Note: In traces without the "Java" category there will be no VSync
       TraceEvents and this table will be empty.
data_objects.summary_desc: A simple table that checks the time between VSync (this can be used to  determine if we're refreshing at 90 FPS or 60 FPS)

cols.name: slice_id
cols.desc: Slice id of the vsync slice.

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: Timestamp of the vsync slice.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: Duration of the vsync slice.

cols.name: track_id
cols.desc: Track id of the vsync slice.

cols.name: time_to_next_vsync
cols.desc: Duration until next vsync arrives.

functions.name: chrome_calculate_avg_vsync_interval
functions.desc:
Function: compute the average Vysnc interval of the
 gesture (hopefully this would be either 60 FPS for the whole gesture or 90
 FPS but that isnt always the case) on the given time segment.
 If the trace doesnt contain the VSync TraceEvent we just fall back on
 assuming its 60 FPS (this is the 1.6e+7 in the COALESCE which
 corresponds to 16 ms or 60 FPS).
functions.summary_desc: Function: compute the average Vysnc interval of the  gesture (hopefully this would be either 60 FPS for the whole gesture or 90  FPS but that isnt always the case) on the given time segment
functions.return_desc: The average vsync interval on this time segment or 1.6e+7, if trace doesn't contain the VSync TraceEvent.

data_objects.name: chrome_interactions
data_objects.desc:
All critical user interaction events, including type and table with
 associated metrics.
data_objects.summary_desc: All critical user interaction events, including type and table with  associated metrics

cols.name: scoped_id
cols.desc: Identifier of the interaction; this is not guaranteed to be unique to the table - rather, it is unique within an individual interaction type. Combine with type to get a unique identifier in this table.

cols.name: type
cols.desc: Type of this interaction, which together with scoped_id uniquely identifies this interaction. Also corresponds to a SQL table name containing more details specific to this type of interaction.

cols.name: name
cols.desc: Interaction name - e.g. 'PageLoad', 'Tap', etc. Interactions will have unique metrics stored in other tables.

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: Timestamp of the CUI event.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: Duration of the CUI event.

data_objects.name: chrome_event_latencies
data_objects.desc: All EventLatency slices.
data_objects.summary_desc: All EventLatency slices

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Slice Id for the EventLatency scroll event.

cols.name: name
cols.desc: Slice name.

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: The start timestamp of the scroll.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: The duration of the scroll.

cols.name: scroll_update_id
cols.desc: The id of the scroll update event (aka LatencyInfo.ID).

cols.name: surface_frame_trace_id
cols.desc: The id of the first frame (pre-surface aggregation) which included the scroll update and was presented. NULL if: (1) the event is not a scroll update (`event_type` is NOT GESTURE_SCROLL_UPDATE, FIRST_GESTURE_SCROLL_UPDATE, or INERTIAL_GESTURE_SCROLL_UPDATE), (2) the scroll update wasn't presented (e.g. it was an overscroll) or (3) the trace comes from an old Chrome version (https://crrev.com/c/6185817 was first included in version 134.0.6977.0 and was cherry-picked in version 133.0.6943.33).

cols.name: display_trace_id
cols.desc: The id of the first frame (post-surface aggregation) which included the scroll update and was presented. NULL if: (1) the event is not a scroll update (`event_type` is NOT GESTURE_SCROLL_UPDATE, FIRST_GESTURE_SCROLL_UPDATE, or INERTIAL_GESTURE_SCROLL_UPDATE), (2) the scroll update wasn't presented (e.g. it was an overscroll) or (3) the trace comes from an old Chrome version (https://crrev.com/c/6185817 was first included in version 134.0.6977.0 and was cherry-picked in version 133.0.6943.33).

cols.name: is_presented
cols.desc: Whether this input event was presented.

cols.name: event_type
cols.desc: EventLatency event type.

cols.name: track_id
cols.desc: Perfetto track this slice is found on.

cols.name: vsync_interval_ms
cols.desc: Vsync interval (in milliseconds).

cols.name: is_janky_scrolled_frame
cols.desc: Whether the corresponding frame is janky based on the Event.ScrollJank.DelayedFramesPercentage.FixedWindow metric.

cols.name: buffer_available_timestamp
cols.desc: Timestamp of the BufferAvailableToBufferReady substage.

cols.name: buffer_ready_timestamp
cols.desc: Timestamp of the BufferReadyToLatch substage.

cols.name: latch_timestamp
cols.desc: Timestamp of the LatchToSwapEnd substage (or LatchToPresentation as a fallback).

cols.name: swap_end_timestamp
cols.desc: Timestamp of the SwapEndToPresentationCompositorFrame substage.

cols.name: presentation_timestamp
cols.desc: Frame presentation timestamp aka the timestamp of the SwapEndToPresentationCompositorFrame substage. TODO(b/341047059): temporarily use LatchToSwapEnd as a workaround if SwapEndToPresentationCompositorFrame is missing due to b/247542163.

table_functions.name: chrome_select_scroll_jank_cause_thread
table_functions.desc:
Function to retrieve the thread id of the thread on a particular process if
 there are any slices during a particular EventLatency slice duration; this
 upid/thread combination refers to a cause of Scroll Jank.
table_functions.summary_desc: Function to retrieve the thread id of the thread on a particular process if  there are any slices during a particular EventLatency slice duration; this  upid/thread combination refers to a cause of Scroll Jank

args.name: event_latency_id
args.desc: The slice id of an EventLatency slice.

args.name: process_type
args.desc: The process type that the thread is on: one of 'Browser', 'Renderer' or 'GPU'.

data_objects.name: chrome_predictor_error
data_objects.desc:
The scrolling offsets and predictor jank values for the actual (applied)
 scroll events.
data_objects.summary_desc: The scrolling offsets and predictor jank values for the actual (applied)  scroll events

cols.name: scroll_id
cols.desc: An ID that ties all EventLatencies in a particular scroll. (implementation note: This is the EventLatency TraceId of the GestureScrollbegin).

cols.name: scroll_update_id
cols.desc: An ID that ties this |event_latency_id| with the Trace Id (another event_latency_id) that it was presented with.

cols.name: present_ts
cols.desc: Presentation timestamp.

cols.name: delta_y
cols.desc: The delta in raw coordinates between this presented EventLatency and the previous presented frame.

cols.name: relative_offset_y
cols.desc: The pixel offset of this presented EventLatency compared to the initial one.

cols.name: prev_delta
cols.desc: The delta in raw coordinates of the previous scroll update event.

cols.name: next_delta
cols.desc: The delta in raw coordinates of the subsequent scroll update event.

cols.name: predictor_jank
cols.desc: The jank value based on the discrepancy between scroll predictor coordinates and the actual deltas between scroll update events.

cols.name: delta_threshold
cols.desc: The threshold used to determine if jank occurred.

data_objects.name: chrome_scroll_input_deltas

data_objects.summary_desc: The raw input deltas for all input events which were part of a scroll

cols.name: scroll_update_id
cols.desc: Scroll update id (aka LatencyInfo.ID) for this scroll update input event.

cols.desc: The delta in pixels (scaled to the device's screen size) how much this input event moved over the X axis vs previous, as reported by the OS.

cols.name: delta_y
cols.desc: The delta in pixels (scaled to the device's screen size) how much this input event moved over the Y axis vs previous, as reported by the OS.

cols.desc: Timestamp the of the scroll input event.

cols.name: delta_y
cols.desc: The delta in raw coordinates between this scroll update event and the previous.

cols.name: relative_offset_y

data_objects.name: chrome_scroll_presented_deltas
data_objects.desc:
The page offset delta (by how much the page was scrolled vs previous frame)
 for each frame.
 This is the resulting delta that is shown to the user after the input has
 been processed. `chrome_scroll_input_deltas` tracks the underlying signal
 deltas between consecutive input events.
data_objects.summary_desc: The page offset delta (by how much the page was scrolled vs previous frame)  for each frame

cols.name: scroll_update_id
cols.desc: Scroll update id (aka LatencyInfo.ID) for this scroll update input event.

cols.name: delta_x
cols.desc: The delta in pixels (scaled to the device's screen size) how much this input event moved over the X axis vs previous, as reported by the OS.

cols.name: delta_y
cols.desc: The delta in pixels (scaled to the device's screen size) how much this input event moved over the Y axis vs previous, as reported by the OS.

cols.name: offset_x
cols.desc: The page offset in pixels (scaled to the device's screen size) along the X axis.

cols.name: offset_y
cols.desc: The page offset in pixels (scaled to the device's screen size) along the Y axis.

data_objects.name: chrome_presented_scroll_offsets
data_objects.desc:
The scrolling offsets for the actual (applied) scroll events. These are not
 necessarily inclusive of all user scroll events, rather those scroll events
 that are actually processed.

functions.name: chrome_get_v3_jank_cause_id
functions.desc:
Given two slice Ids A and B, find the maximum difference
 between the durations of it's direct children with matching names
 for example if slice A has children named (X, Y, Z) with durations of (10, 10, 5)
 and slice B has children named (X, Y) with durations of (9, 9), the function will return
 the slice id of the slice named Z that is A's child, as no matching slice named Z was found
 under B, making 5 - 0 = 5 the maximum delta between both slice's direct children
functions.summary_desc: Given two slice Ids A and B, find the maximum difference  between the durations of it's direct children with matching names  for example if slice A has children named (X, Y, Z) with durations of (10, 10, 5)  and slice B has children named (X, Y) with durations of (9, 9), the function will return  the slice id of the slice named Z that is A's child, as no matching slice named Z was found  under B, making 5 - 0 = 5 the maximum delta between both slice's direct children

args.name: janky_slice_id
args.desc: The slice id of the parent slice that we want to cause among it's children.

args.name: prev_slice_id
args.desc: The slice id of the parent slice that's the reference in comparison to |janky_slice_id|.

functions.return_desc: The slice id of the breakdown that has the maximum duration delta.

macros.name: interval_self_intersect
macros.desc:
Given a list of intervals (ts, dur), this macro generates a list of interval
 end points as well as the intervals that intersect with those points.

 e.g. input (10, 20), (20, 25)

         10      30
        A |-------|
             B|----------|
             20         45

 would generate the output:
 ```
 ts,dur,group_id,id,interval_ends_at_ts
 10,10,1,A,0
 20,10,2,A,0
 20,10,2,B,0
 30,15,3,A,1
 30,15,3,B,0
 45,0,4,B,1
 ```

 Runtime is O(n log n + m), where n is the number of intervals and m
 is the size of the output.
macros.summary_desc: Given a list of intervals (ts, dur), this macro generates a list of interval  end points as well as the intervals that intersect with those points

args.name: intervals
args.desc: Table or subquery containing interval data.

macros.name: intervals_overlap_count
macros.desc:
Compute the distribution of the overlap of the given intervals over time.

 Each interval is a (ts, dur) pair and the overlap represented as a (ts, value)
 counter, with the value corresponding to the number of intervals that overlap
 the given timestamp and interval until the next timestamp.
macros.summary_desc: Compute the distribution of the overlap of the given intervals over time
macros.return_desc: The returned table has the schema (ts TIMESTAMP, value LONG). |ts| is the timestamp when the number of open segments changed. |value| is the number of open segments.

args.name: segments
args.desc: Table or subquery containing interval data.

macros.name: intervals_overlap_count_by_group
macros.desc:
Compute the distribution of the overlap of the given intervals over time from
 slices in a same group.

 Each interval is a (ts, dur, group) triple and the overlap represented as a
 (ts, value, group) counter, with the value corresponding to the number of
 intervals that belong to the same group and overlap the given timestamp and
 interval until the next timestamp.
macros.summary_desc: Compute the distribution of the overlap of the given intervals over time from  slices in a same group
macros.return_desc: The returned table has the schema (ts INT64, value UINT32, group_name) where the type of group_name is the same as that in |segments|. |ts| is the timestamp when the number of open segments changed. |value| is the number of open segments. |group_name| is the name of a group used for the overlap calculation.

args.name: segments
args.desc: Table or subquery containing interval data.

args.name: group_column
args.desc: Column containing group name for grouping.

macros.name: interval_merge_overlapping
macros.desc:
Merge intervals when they overlap to generate a minimum covering set of
 intervals with no overlap. The intervals are closed (contain both endpoints)
 and we consider two intervals overlapping
   (a) the intervals overlap or
   (b) if the end point of one interval is within epsilon of the start point
       of the other.
macros.summary_desc: Merge intervals when they overlap to generate a minimum covering set of  intervals with no overlap

args.name: intervals
args.desc: Table or subquery containing interval data.

args.name: epsilon
args.desc: Constant expression for a tolerance in testing overlap (usually `0`)

macros.name: interval_merge_overlapping_partitioned
macros.desc:
Merge overlapping intervals within each partition group to generate a minimum
 covering set of intervals with no overlap within each partition.

 For each partition, this macro merges overlapping intervals into
 non-overlapping intervals. The result contains intervals where at least
 one input interval is active.

 For example, with partition 'A':
   Input: (ts=1, dur=10), (ts=5, dur=12)
   Output: (ts=1, dur=16)
macros.summary_desc: Merge overlapping intervals within each partition group to generate a minimum  covering set of intervals with no overlap within each partition
macros.return_desc: The returned table has the schema (ts TIMESTAMP, dur DURATION, partitions). |ts| is the start of the merged interval. |dur| is the duration of the merged interval. |partitions| is all of the columns in partition_columns.

args.name: intervals
args.desc: Table or subquery containing interval data.

For each thread slice, returns the sum of the time it spent in various
 scheduling states.

 Requires scheduling data to be available in the trace.

cols.desc: Name of the thread.

cols.name: upid
cols.desc: Id of the process the slice is running on.

cols.name: process_name
cols.desc: Name of the process.

cols.name: state
cols.desc: The scheduling state (from the `thread_state` table).  Use the `sched_state_to_human_readable_string` function in the `sched` package to get full name.

cols.name: io_wait
cols.desc: If the `state` is uninterruptible sleep, `io_wait` indicates if it was an IO sleep. Will be null if `state` is *not* uninterruptible sleep or if we cannot tell if it was an IO sleep or not.  Only available on Android when `sched/sched_blocked_reason` ftrace tracepoint is enabled.

cols.name: blocked_function
cols.desc: If in uninterruptible sleep (D), the kernel function on which was blocked. Only available on userdebug Android builds when `sched/sched_blocked_reason` ftrace tracepoint is enabled.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: The duration of time the threads slice spent for each (state, io_wait, blocked_function) tuple.

module_doc.name: prelude.after_eof.core
module_doc.desc:
Fundamental trace concepts and infrastructure.

This module provides the core tables and views that represent fundamental
trace concepts like trace boundaries and available metrics.
Lists all metrics built-into trace processor.

data_objects.name: trace_metrics
data_objects.desc: Lists all metrics built-into trace processor.
data_objects.summary_desc: Lists all metrics built-into trace processor

cols.name: name
cols.desc: The name of the metric.

data_objects.name: trace_bounds
data_objects.desc:
Definition of `trace_bounds` table. The values are being filled by Trace
 Processor when parsing the trace.
 It is recommended to depend on the `trace_start()` and `trace_end()`
 functions rather than directly on `trace_bounds`.
data_objects.summary_desc: Definition of `trace_bounds` table

cols.name: start_ts
cols.desc: First ts in the trace.

cols.name: end_ts
cols.desc: End of the trace.

functions.name: slice_is_ancestor
functions.desc: Given two slice ids, returns whether the first is an ancestor of the second.
functions.summary_desc: Given two slice ids, returns whether the first is an ancestor of the second

args.name: ancestor_id
args.desc: Id of the potential ancestor slice.

args.name: descendant_id
args.desc: Id of the potential descendant slice.

functions.return_desc: Whether `ancestor_id` slice is an ancestor of `descendant_id`.

module_doc.name: prelude.after_eof.memory
module_doc.desc:
Memory and heap analysis tables.

This module provides tables and views for analyzing memory usage,
including heap graphs for Android Runtime (ART) and memory snapshots
for detailed memory profiling.

data_objects.name: heap_graph_class
data_objects.desc:
Stores class information within ART heap graphs. It represents Java/Kotlin
 classes that exist in the heap, including their names, inheritance
 relationships, and loading context.
data_objects.summary_desc: Stores class information within ART heap graphs

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Unique identifier for this heap graph class.

cols.name: name
cols.desc: (potentially obfuscated) name of the class.

cols.name: deobfuscated_name
cols.desc: If class name was obfuscated and deobfuscation map for it provided, the deobfuscated name.

cols.name: location
cols.desc: the APK / Dex / JAR file the class is contained in.

cols.name: superclass_id
cols.desc: The superclass of this class.

cols.name: classloader_id
cols.desc: The classloader that loaded this class.

cols.name: kind
cols.desc: The kind of class.

data_objects.name: heap_graph_object
data_objects.desc:
The objects on the Dalvik heap.

 All rows with the same (upid, graph_sample_ts) are one dump.
data_objects.summary_desc: The objects on the Dalvik heap

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Unique identifier for this heap graph object.

cols.name: upid
cols.desc: Unique PID of the target.

cols.name: graph_sample_ts
cols.desc: Timestamp this dump was taken at.

cols.name: self_size
cols.desc: Size this object uses on the Java Heap.

cols.name: native_size
cols.desc: Approximate amount of native memory used by this object, as reported by libcore.util.NativeAllocationRegistry.size.

cols.name: reference_set_id
cols.desc: Join key with heap_graph_reference containing all objects referred in this object's fields.

cols.name: reachable
cols.desc: Bool whether this object is reachable from a GC root. If false, this object is uncollected garbage.

cols.name: heap_type
cols.desc: The type of ART heap this object is stored on (app, zygote, boot image)

cols.name: type_id
cols.desc: Class this object is an instance of.

cols.name: root_type
cols.desc: If not NULL, this object is a GC root.

cols.name: root_distance
cols.desc: Distance from the root object.

data_objects.name: heap_graph_reference
data_objects.desc:
Many-to-many mapping between heap_graph_object.

 This associates the object with given reference_set_id with the objects
 that are referred to by its fields.
data_objects.summary_desc: Many-to-many mapping between heap_graph_object

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Unique identifier for this heap graph reference.

cols.name: reference_set_id
cols.desc: Join key to heap_graph_object reference_set_id.

cols.name: owner_id
cols.desc: Id of object that has this reference_set_id.

cols.name: owned_id
cols.desc: Id of object that is referred to.

cols.name: field_name
cols.desc: The field that refers to the object. E.g. Foo.name.

cols.name: field_type_name
cols.desc: The static type of the field. E.g. java.lang.String.

cols.name: deobfuscated_field_name
cols.desc: The deobfuscated name, if field_name was obfuscated and a deobfuscation mapping was provided for it.

module_doc.name: prelude.after_eof.events
module_doc.desc:
Event data and slices for trace analysis.

This module provides tables and views for analyzing various types of
events and slices including ftrace events, graphics frames, GPU events,
and frame timeline information.

data_objects.name: ftrace_event
data_objects.desc:
Contains all the ftrace events in the trace. This table exists only for
 debugging purposes and should not be relied on in production usecases (i.e.
 metrics, standard library etc). Note also that this table might be empty if
 raw ftrace parsing has been disabled.
data_objects.summary_desc: Contains all the ftrace events in the trace

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Unique identifier for this ftrace event.

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: The timestamp of this event.

cols.name: name
cols.desc: The ftrace event name.

cols.name: cpu
cols.desc: The CPU this event was emitted on (meaningful only in single machine traces). For multi-machine, join with the `cpu` table on `ucpu` to get the CPU identifier of each machine.

cols.name: utid
cols.desc: The thread this event was emitted on.

cols.name: arg_set_id
cols.desc: The set of key/value pairs associated with this event.

cols.name: common_flags
cols.desc: Ftrace event flags for this event. Currently only emitted for sched_waking events.

cols.name: ucpu
cols.desc: The unique CPU identifier that this event was emitted on.

data_objects.name: raw
data_objects.desc:
This table is deprecated. Use `ftrace_event` instead which contains the same
 rows; this table is simply a (badly named) alias.
data_objects.summary_desc: This table is deprecated

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Unique identifier for this raw event.

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: The timestamp of this event.

cols.name: name
cols.desc: The name of the event. For ftrace events, this will be the ftrace event name.

cols.name: cpu
cols.desc: The CPU this event was emitted on (meaningful only in single machine traces). For multi-machine, join with the `cpu` table on `ucpu` to get the CPU identifier of each machine.

cols.name: utid
cols.desc: The thread this event was emitted on.

cols.name: arg_set_id
cols.desc: The set of key/value pairs associated with this event.

cols.name: common_flags
cols.desc: Ftrace event flags for this event. Currently only emitted for sched_waking events.

cols.name: ucpu
cols.desc: The unique CPU identifier that this event was emitted on.

modules.data_check_sql: SELECT EXISTS(SELECT 1 FROM __intrinsic_ftrace_event LIMIT 1) AS has_data

module_doc.name: prelude.after_eof.counters
module_doc.desc:
Performance counters and counter tracks.

This module provides counter-related tables and views for analyzing
performance metrics collected across CPUs, processes, threads, GPUs,
and other contexts.

data_objects.name: counter_track
data_objects.desc: Tracks containing counter-like events.
data_objects.summary_desc: Tracks containing counter-like events

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Unique identifier for this cpu counter track.

cols.name: name
cols.desc: Name of the track.

cols.name: parent_id
cols.desc: The track which is the "parent" of this track. Only non-null for tracks created using Perfetto's track_event API.

cols.name: type
cols.desc: The type of a track indicates the type of data the track contains.  Every track is uniquely identified by the the combination of the type and a set of dimensions: type allow identifying a set of tracks with the same type of data within the whole universe of tracks while dimensions allow distinguishing between different tracks in that set.

cols.name: dimension_arg_set_id
cols.desc: The dimensions of the track which uniquely identify the track within a given type.

cols.name: source_arg_set_id
cols.desc: Args for this track which store information about "source" of this track in the trace. For example: whether this track orginated from atrace, Chrome tracepoints etc.

cols.name: machine_id
cols.desc: Machine identifier

cols.name: unit
cols.desc: The units of the counter. This column is rarely filled.

cols.name: description
cols.desc: The description for this track. For debugging purposes only.

module_doc.name: prelude.after_eof.tracks
module_doc.desc:
Track infrastructure for organizing trace events.

This module provides the track concept and specialized track tables for
organizing events by thread, process, CPU, and GPU contexts.

data_objects.name: track
data_objects.desc:
Tracks are a fundamental concept in trace processor and represent a
 "timeline" for events of the same type and with the same context. See
 https://perfetto.dev/docs/analysis/trace-processor#tracks for a more
 detailed explanation, with examples.
data_objects.summary_desc: Tracks are a fundamental concept in trace processor and represent a  "timeline" for events of the same type and with the same context

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Unique identifier for this track. Identical to |track_id|, prefer using |track_id| instead.

cols.name: name
cols.desc: Name of the track; can be null for some types of tracks (e.g. thread tracks).

cols.name: type
cols.desc: The type of a track indicates the type of data the track contains.  Every track is uniquely identified by the the combination of the type and a set of dimensions: type allow identifying a set of tracks with the same type of data within the whole universe of tracks while dimensions allow distinguishing between different tracks in that set.

cols.name: dimension_arg_set_id
cols.desc: The dimensions of the track which uniquely identify the track within a given `type`.  Join with the `args` table or use the `EXTRACT_ARG` helper function to expand the args.

cols.name: parent_id
cols.desc: The track which is the "parent" of this track. Only non-null for tracks created using Perfetto's track_event API.

cols.name: source_arg_set_id
cols.desc: Generic key-value pairs containing extra information about the track.  Join with the `args` table or use the `EXTRACT_ARG` helper function to expand the args.

cols.name: machine_id
cols.desc: Machine identifier

cols.name: track_group_id
cols.desc: An opaque key indicating that this track belongs to a group of tracks which are "conceptually" the same track.  Tracks in trace processor don't allow overlapping events to allow for easy analysis (i.e. SQL window functions, SPAN JOIN and other similar operators). However, in visualization settings (e.g. the UI), the distinction doesn't matter and all tracks with the same `track_group_id` should be merged together into a single logical "UI track".

data_objects.name: thread_track
data_objects.desc: Tracks which are associated to a single thread.
data_objects.summary_desc: Tracks which are associated to a single thread

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Unique identifier for this thread track.

cols.name: name
cols.desc: Name of the track.

cols.name: type
cols.desc: The type of a track indicates the type of data the track contains.  Every track is uniquely identified by the the combination of the type and a set of dimensions: type allow identifying a set of tracks with the same type of data within the whole universe of tracks while dimensions allow distinguishing between different tracks in that set.

cols.name: parent_id
cols.desc: The track which is the "parent" of this track. Only non-null for tracks created using Perfetto's track_event API.

cols.name: source_arg_set_id
cols.desc: Args for this track which store information about "source" of this track in the trace. For example: whether this track orginated from atrace, Chrome tracepoints etc.

cols.name: machine_id
cols.desc: Machine identifier

cols.name: utid
cols.desc: The utid that the track is associated with.

Every track is uniquely identified by the the combination of the type and a set of dimensions: type allow identifying a set of tracks with the same type of data within the whole universe of tracks while dimensions allow distinguishing between different tracks in that set.

data_objects.desc:
Table containing tracks which are loosely tied to a GPU.

 NOTE: this table is deprecated due to inconsistency of it's design with
 other track tables (e.g. not having a GPU column, mixing a bunch of different
 tracks which are barely related). Please use the track table directly
 instead.
data_objects.summary_desc: Table containing tracks which are loosely tied to a GPU

cols.name: name

Every track is uniquely identified by the the combination of the type and a set of dimensions: type allow identifying a set of tracks with the same type of data within the whole universe of tracks while dimensions allow distinguishing between different tracks in that set.

cols.desc: The dimensions of the track which uniquely identify the track within a given type.

cols.desc: Machine identifier

cols.desc: The source of the track. Deprecated.

cols.desc: The description for the track.

cols.name: context_id
cols.desc: The context id for the GPU this track is associated to.

module_doc.name: prelude.after_eof.cpu_scheduling
module_doc.desc:
CPU scheduling and thread state analysis.

This module provides tables and views for analyzing CPU scheduling behavior,
including scheduling slices, thread states, and CPU information.

data_objects.name: cpu
data_objects.desc: Contains information about the CPUs on the device this trace was taken on.
data_objects.summary_desc: Contains information about the CPUs on the device this trace was taken on

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Unique identifier for this CPU. Identical to |ucpu|, prefer using |ucpu| instead.

cols.name: ucpu
cols.desc: Unique identifier for this CPU. Isn't equal to |cpu| for remote machines and is equal to |cpu| for the host machine.

cols.name: cpu
cols.desc: The 0-based CPU core identifier.

cols.name: cluster_id
cols.desc: The cluster id is shared by CPUs in the same cluster.

cols.name: processor
cols.desc: A string describing this core.

cols.name: machine_id
cols.desc: Machine identifier

cols.name: capacity
cols.desc: Capacity of a CPU of a device, a metric which indicates the relative performance of a CPU on a device For details see: https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/devicetree/bindings/arm/cpu-capacity.txt

cols.name: arg_set_id
cols.desc: Extra key/value pairs associated with this cpu.

data_objects.name: cpu_available_frequencies
data_objects.desc:
Contains the frequency values that the CPUs on the device are capable of
 running at.
data_objects.summary_desc: Contains the frequency values that the CPUs on the device are capable of  running at

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Unique identifier for this cpu frequency.

cols.name: cpu
cols.desc: The CPU for this frequency, meaningful only in single machine traces. For multi-machine, join with the `cpu` table on `ucpu` to get the CPU identifier of each machine.

cols.name: freq
cols.desc: CPU frequency in KHz.

cols.name: ucpu
cols.desc: The CPU that the slice executed on (meaningful only in single machine traces). For multi-machine, join with the `cpu` table on `ucpu` to get the CPU identifier of each machine.

data_objects.name: sched
data_objects.desc:
Contains scheduling slices with kernel thread scheduling information.
 These slices are collected when the Linux "ftrace" data source is used with
 the "sched/switch" and "sched/wakeup*" events enabled.

 The rows in this view will always have a matching row in the |thread_state|
 table with |thread_state.state| = 'Running'
data_objects.summary_desc: Contains scheduling slices with kernel thread scheduling information

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Unique identifier for this scheduling slice.

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: The timestamp at the start of the slice.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: The duration of the slice.

cols.name: cpu
cols.desc: The CPU that the slice executed on (meaningful only in single machine traces). For multi-machine, join with the `cpu` table on `ucpu` to get the CPU identifier of each machine.

cols.name: utid
cols.desc: The thread's unique id in the trace.

cols.name: end_state
cols.desc: A string representing the scheduling state of the kernel thread at the end of the slice.  The individual characters in the string mean the following: R (runnable), S (awaiting a wakeup), D (in an uninterruptible sleep), T (suspended), t (being traced), X (exiting), P (parked), W (waking), I (idle), N (not contributing to the load average), K (wakeable on fatal signals) and Z (zombie, awaiting cleanup).

cols.name: priority
cols.desc: The kernel priority that the thread ran at.

cols.name: ucpu
cols.desc: The unique CPU identifier that the slice executed on.

cols.name: ts_end
cols.desc: Legacy column, should no longer be used.

data_objects.name: sched_slice
data_objects.desc: Alias of `sched`. Prefer using `sched` instead.
data_objects.summary_desc: Alias of `sched`

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Alias of `sched.id`.

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: Alias of `sched.ts`.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: Alias of `sched.dur`.

cols.name: cpu
cols.desc: Alias of `sched.cpu`.

cols.name: utid
cols.desc: Alias of `sched.utid`.

cols.name: end_state
cols.desc: Alias of `sched.end_state`.

cols.name: priority
cols.desc: Alias of `sched.priority`.

cols.name: ucpu
cols.desc: Alias of `sched.ucpu`.

data_objects.name: thread_state
data_objects.desc:
This table contains the scheduling state of every thread on the system during
 the trace.

 The rows in this table which have |state| = 'Running', will have a
 corresponding row in the |sched_slice| table.
data_objects.summary_desc: This table contains the scheduling state of every thread on the system during  the trace

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Unique identifier for this thread state.

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: The timestamp at the start of the slice.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: The duration of the slice.

cols.name: cpu
cols.desc: The CPU that the thread executed on (meaningful only in single machine traces). For multi-machine, join with the `cpu` table on `ucpu` to get the CPU identifier of each machine.

cols.name: utid
cols.desc: The thread's unique id in the trace.

cols.name: state
cols.desc: The scheduling state of the thread. Can be "Running" or any of the states described in |sched_slice.end_state|.

cols.name: io_wait
cols.desc: Indicates whether this thread was blocked on IO.

cols.name: blocked_function
cols.desc: The function in the kernel this thread was blocked on.

cols.name: waker_utid
cols.desc: The unique thread id of the thread which caused a wakeup of this thread.

cols.name: waker_id
cols.desc: The unique thread state id which caused a wakeup of this thread.

cols.name: irq_context
cols.desc: Whether the wakeup was from interrupt context or process context.

cols.name: ucpu
cols.desc: The unique CPU identifier that the thread executed on.

data_objects.name: counter
data_objects.desc: Counters are values put into tracks during parsing of the trace.
data_objects.summary_desc: Counters are values put into tracks during parsing of the trace

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Unique id of a counter value

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: Time of fetching the counter value.

cols.name: track_id
cols.desc: Track this counter value belongs to.

cols.name: value
cols.desc: Value.

cols.name: arg_set_id
cols.desc: Additional information about the counter value.

data_objects.name: slice
data_objects.desc:
Contains slices from userspace which explains what threads were doing
 during the trace.
data_objects.summary_desc: Contains slices from userspace which explains what threads were doing  during the trace

cols.name: id
cols.desc: The id of the slice.

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: The timestamp at the start of the slice in nanoseconds. The actual value depends on the `primary_trace_clock` selected in TraceConfig. This is often the value of a monotonic counter since device boot so is only meaningful in the context of a trace.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: The duration of the slice in nanoseconds.

cols.name: track_id
cols.desc: The id of the track this slice is located on.

cols.name: category
cols.desc: The "category" of the slice. If this slice originated with track_event, this column contains the category emitted. Otherwise, it is likely to be null (with limited exceptions).

cols.name: name
cols.desc: The name of the slice. The name describes what was happening during the slice.

cols.name: depth
cols.desc: The depth of the slice in the current stack of slices.

cols.name: parent_id
cols.desc: The id of the parent (i.e. immediate ancestor) slice for this slice.

cols.name: arg_set_id
cols.desc: The id of the argument set associated with this slice.

cols.name: thread_ts
cols.desc: The thread timestamp at the start of the slice. This column will only be populated if thread timestamp collection is enabled with track_event.

cols.name: thread_dur
cols.desc: The thread time used by this slice. This column will only be populated if thread timestamp collection is enabled with track_event.

cols.name: thread_instruction_count
cols.desc: The value of the CPU instruction counter at the start of the slice. This column will only be populated if thread instruction collection is enabled with track_event.

cols.name: thread_instruction_delta
cols.desc: The change in value of the CPU instruction counter between the start and end of the slice. This column will only be populated if thread instruction collection is enabled with track_event.

cols.name: cat
cols.desc: Alias of `category`.

cols.name: slice_id
cols.desc: Alias of `id`.

data_objects.name: instant
data_objects.desc:
Contains instant events from userspace which indicates what happened at a
 single moment in time.
data_objects.summary_desc: Contains instant events from userspace which indicates what happened at a  single moment in time

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: The timestamp of the instant.

cols.name: track_id
cols.desc: The id of the track this instant is located on.

cols.name: name
cols.desc: The name of the instant. The name describes what happened during the instant.

cols.name: arg_set_id
cols.desc: The id of the argument set associated with this instant.

data_objects.name: slices
data_objects.desc: Alternative alias of table `slice`.
data_objects.summary_desc: Alternative alias of table `slice`

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Alias of `slice.id`.

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: Alias of `slice.ts`.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: Alias of `slice.dur`.

cols.name: track_id
cols.desc: Alias of `slice.track_id`.

cols.name: category
cols.desc: Alias of `slice.category`.

cols.name: name
cols.desc: Alias of `slice.name`.

cols.name: depth
cols.desc: Alias of `slice.depth`.

cols.name: parent_id
cols.desc: Alias of `slice.parent_id`.

cols.name: arg_set_id
cols.desc: Alias of `slice.arg_set_id`.

cols.name: thread_ts
cols.desc: Alias of `slice.thread_ts`.

cols.name: thread_dur
cols.desc: Alias of `slice.thread_dur`.

cols.name: thread_instruction_count
cols.desc: Alias of `slice.thread_instruction_count`.

cols.name: thread_instruction_delta
cols.desc: Alias of `slice.thread_instruction_delta`.

cols.name: cat
cols.desc: Alias of `slice.cat`.

cols.name: slice_id
cols.desc: Alias of `slice.slice_id`.

data_objects.name: thread
data_objects.desc: Contains information of threads seen during the trace.
data_objects.summary_desc: Contains information of threads seen during the trace

cols.name: id
cols.desc: The id of the thread. Prefer using `utid` instead.

cols.name: utid
cols.desc: Unique thread id. This is != the OS tid. This is a monotonic number associated to each thread. The OS thread id (tid) cannot be used as primary key because tids and pids are recycled by most kernels.

cols.name: tid
cols.desc: The OS id for this thread. Note: this is *not* unique over the lifetime of the trace so cannot be used as a primary key. Use |utid| instead.

cols.name: name
cols.desc: The name of the thread. Can be populated from many sources (e.g. ftrace, /proc scraping, track event etc).

cols.name: start_ts
cols.desc: The start timestamp of this thread (if known). Is null in most cases unless a thread creation event is enabled (e.g. task_newtask ftrace event on Linux/Android).

cols.name: end_ts
cols.desc: The end timestamp of this thread (if known). Is null in most cases unless a thread destruction event is enabled (e.g. sched_process_free ftrace event on Linux/Android).

cols.name: upid
cols.desc: The process hosting this thread.

cols.name: is_main_thread
cols.desc: Boolean indicating if this thread is the main thread in the process.

cols.name: is_idle
cols.desc: Boolean indicating if this thread is a kernel idle thread.

cols.name: machine_id
cols.desc: Machine identifier

cols.name: arg_set_id
cols.desc: Extra args for this thread.

data_objects.name: process
data_objects.desc: Contains information of processes seen during the trace.
data_objects.summary_desc: Contains information of processes seen during the trace

cols.name: id
cols.desc: The id of the process. Prefer using `upid` instead.

cols.name: upid
cols.desc: Unique process id. This is != the OS pid. This is a monotonic number associated to each process. The OS process id (pid) cannot be used as primary key because tids and pids are recycled by most kernels.

cols.name: pid
cols.desc: The OS id for this process. Note: this is *not* unique over the lifetime of the trace so cannot be used as a primary key. Use |upid| instead.

cols.name: name
cols.desc: The name of the process. Can be populated from many sources (e.g. ftrace, /proc scraping, track event etc).

cols.name: start_ts
cols.desc: The start timestamp of this process (if known). Is null in most cases unless a process creation event is enabled (e.g. task_newtask ftrace event on Linux/Android).

cols.name: end_ts
cols.desc: The end timestamp of this process (if known). Is null in most cases unless a process destruction event is enabled (e.g. sched_process_free ftrace event on Linux/Android).

cols.name: parent_upid
cols.desc: The upid of the process which caused this process to be spawned.

cols.name: uid

functions.name: export_to_firefox_profile
functions.desc:
Dumps all trace data as a Firefox profile json string
 See `Profile` in
 https://github.com/firefox-devtools/profiler/blob/main/src/types/profile.js
 Also
 https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/tools/profiler/code-overview.html

 You would probably want to download the generated json and then open at
 https://https://profiler.firefox.com
 You can easily do this from the UI via the following SQL
 `SELECT CAST(export_to_firefox_profile() AS BLOB) AS profile;`
 The result will have a link for you to download this json as a file.
functions.summary_desc: Dumps all trace data as a Firefox profile json string  See `Profile` in  https://github

data_objects.name: sched_latency_for_running_interval
data_objects.desc:
Scheduling latency of running thread states.
 For each time the thread was running, returns the duration of the runnable
 state directly before.
data_objects.summary_desc: Scheduling latency of running thread states

cols.name: thread_state_id
cols.desc: Running state of the thread.

cols.name: sched_id
cols.desc: Id of a corresponding slice in a `sched` table.

cols.name: utid
cols.desc: Thread with running state.

cols.name: runnable_latency_id
cols.desc: Runnable state before thread is "running". Duration of this thread state is `latency_dur`. One of `thread_state.id`.

cols.name: latency_dur
cols.desc: Scheduling latency of thread state. Duration of thread state with `runnable_latency_id`.

cols.name: time_in_state

data_objects.desc:
Summary of time spent by thread in each scheduling state, in percentage ([0, 100]
 ranges). Sum of all states might be smaller than 100, as those values
 are rounded down.

cols.name: utid
cols.desc: Utid of the thread.

cols.name: running

cols.name: runnable
cols.desc: Percentage of time thread spent in runnable ('R') state in [0, 100] range.

cols.name: runnable_preempted
cols.desc: Percentage of time thread spent in preempted runnable ('R+') state in [0, 100] range.

table_functions.name: sched_time_in_state_for_thread_in_interval
table_functions.desc:
Time the thread spent each state in a given interval.

 This function is only designed to run over a small number of intervals
 (10-100 at most). It will be *very slow* for large sets of intervals.

 Specifically for any non-trivial subset of thread slices, prefer using
 `thread_slice_time_in_state` in the `slices.time_in_state` module for this
 purpose instead.
table_functions.summary_desc: Time the thread spent each state in a given interval

cols.name: state
cols.desc: The scheduling state (from the `thread_state` table).  Use the `sched_state_to_human_readable_string` function in the `sched` package to get full name.

cols.name: io_wait
cols.desc: A (posssibly NULL) boolean indicating, if the device was in uninterruptible sleep, if it was an IO sleep.

cols.name: blocked_function
cols.desc: If the `state` is uninterruptible sleep, `io_wait` indicates if it was an IO sleep. Will be null if `state` is *not* uninterruptible sleep or if we cannot tell if it was an IO sleep or not.  Only available on Android when `sched/sched_blocked_reason` ftrace tracepoint is enabled.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: The duration of time the threads slice spent for each (state, io_wait, blocked_function) tuple.

table_functions.name: sched_time_in_state_and_cpu_for_thread_in_interval
table_functions.desc:
Time the thread spent each state and cpu in a given interval.

 This function is only designed to run over a small number of intervals
 (10-100 at most). It will be *very slow* for large sets of intervals.
table_functions.summary_desc: Time the thread spent each state and cpu in a given interval

cols.name: state
cols.desc: Thread state (from the `thread_state` table). Use `sched_state_to_human_readable_string` function to get full name.

cols.name: io_wait
cols.desc: A (posssibly NULL) boolean indicating, if the device was in uninterruptible sleep, if it was an IO sleep.

cols.name: cpu
cols.desc: Id of the CPU.

cols.name: blocked_function
cols.desc: Some states can specify the blocked function. Usually NULL.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: Total time spent with this state, cpu and blocked function.

table_functions.name: sched_time_in_state_for_cpu_in_interval
table_functions.desc:
Time spent by CPU in each scheduling state in a provided interval.

 This function is only designed to run over a small number of intervals
 (10-100 at most). It will be *very slow* for large sets of intervals.
table_functions.summary_desc: Time spent by CPU in each scheduling state in a provided interval

cols.name: end_state
cols.desc: End state. From `sched.end_state`.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: Duration in state.

data_objects.name: sched_with_thread_process
data_objects.desc:
View of scheduling slices with extended information.
 It holds slices with kernel thread scheduling information. These slices are
 collected when the Linux "ftrace" data source is used with the
 "sched/switch" and "sched/wakeup*" events enabled.

 The rows in this table will always have a matching row in the |thread_state|
 table with |thread_state.state| = 'Running'
data_objects.summary_desc: View of scheduling slices with extended information

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Unique identifier for this scheduling slice (Running period).

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: The timestamp at the start of the Running period.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: The duration of the Running period.

cols.name: utid
cols.desc: Unique identifier of the thread that was running.

cols.name: thread_name
cols.desc: Name of the thread that was running.

cols.name: upid
cols.desc: Unique identifier of the process that the thread belongs to.

cols.name: process_name
cols.desc: Name of the process that the thread belongs to.

cols.name: cpu
cols.desc: The CPU that the slice executed on (meaningful only in single machine traces). For multi-machine, join with the `cpu` table on `ucpu` to get the CPU identifier of each machine.

cols.name: end_state
cols.desc: A string representing the scheduling state of the kernel thread at the end of the slice.  The individual characters in the string mean the following: R (runnable), S (awaiting a wakeup), D (in an uninterruptible sleep), T (suspended), t (being traced), X (exiting), P (parked), W (waking), I (idle), N (not contributing to the load average), K (wakeable on fatal signals) and Z (zombie, awaiting cleanup).

cols.name: priority
cols.desc: The kernel priority that the thread ran at.

functions.return_desc: Humanly readable string representing the scheduling state of the kernel thread. The individual characters in the string mean the following: R (runnable), S (awaiting a wakeup), D (in an uninterruptible sleep), T (suspended), t (being traced), X (exiting), P (parked), W (waking), I (idle), N (not contributing to the load average), K (wakeable on fatal signals) and Z (zombie, awaiting cleanup).

functions.name: sched_state_io_to_human_readable_string

macros.name: graph_reachable_dfs
macros.desc:
Computes the "reachable" set of nodes in a directed graph from a given set
 of starting nodes by performing a depth-first search on the graph. The
 returned nodes are structured as a tree with parent-child relationships
 corresponding to the order in which nodes were encountered by the DFS.

 While this macro can be used directly by end users (hence being public),
 it is primarily intended as a lower-level building block upon which higher
 level functions/macros in the standard library can be built.

 Example usage on traces containing heap graphs:
 ```
 -- Compute the reachable nodes from the first heap root.
 SELECT *
 FROM graph_reachable_dfs!(
   (
     SELECT
       owner_id AS source_node_id,
       owned_id as dest_node_id
     FROM heap_graph_reference
     WHERE owned_id IS NOT NULL
   ),
   (SELECT id FROM heap_graph_object WHERE root_type IS NOT NULL)
 );
 ```
macros.summary_desc: Computes the "reachable" set of nodes in a directed graph from a given set  of starting nodes by performing a depth-first search on the graph
macros.return_desc: The returned table has the schema (node_id LONG, parent_node_id LONG). |node_id| is the id of the node from the input graph and |parent_node_id| is the id of the node which was the first encountered predecessor in a DFS search of the graph.

args.name: graph_table
args.desc: A table/view/subquery corresponding to a directed graph on which the reachability search should be performed. This table must have the columns "source_node_id" and "dest_node_id" corresponding to the two nodes on either end of the edges in the graph.  Note: the columns must contain uint32 similar to ids in trace processor tables (i.e. the values should be relatively dense and close to zero). The implementation makes assumptions on this for performance reasons and, if this criteria is not, can lead to enormous amounts of memory being allocated.

args.name: start_nodes
args.desc: A table/view/subquery corresponding to the list of start nodes for the BFS. This table must have a single column "node_id".

macros.name: graph_reachable_bfs
macros.desc:
Computes the "reachable" set of nodes in a directed graph from a given
 starting node by performing a breadth-first search on the graph. The returned
 nodes are structured as a tree with parent-child relationships corresponding
 to the order in which nodes were encountered by the BFS.

 While this macro can be used directly by end users (hence being public),
 it is primarily intended as a lower-level building block upon which higher
 level functions/macros in the standard library can be built.

 Example usage on traces containing heap graphs:
 ```
 -- Compute the reachable nodes from all heap roots.
 SELECT *
 FROM graph_reachable_bfs!(
   (
     SELECT
       owner_id AS source_node_id,
       owned_id as dest_node_id
     FROM heap_graph_reference
     WHERE owned_id IS NOT NULL
   ),
   (SELECT id FROM heap_graph_object WHERE root_type IS NOT NULL)
 );
 ```
macros.summary_desc: Computes the "reachable" set of nodes in a directed graph from a given  starting node by performing a breadth-first search on the graph
macros.return_desc: The returned table has the schema (node_id LONG, parent_node_id LONG). |node_id| is the id of the node from the input graph and |parent_node_id| is the id of the node which was the first encountered predecessor in a BFS search of the graph.

args.name: graph_table
args.desc: A table/view/subquery corresponding to a directed graph on which the reachability search should be performed. This table must have the columns "source_node_id" and "dest_node_id" corresponding to the two nodes on either end of the edges in the graph.  Note: the columns must contain uint32 similar to ids in trace processor tables (i.e. the values should be relatively dense and close to zero). The implementation makes assumptions on this for performance reasons and, if this criteria is not, can lead to enormous amounts of memory being allocated.

args.name: start_nodes
args.desc: A table/view/subquery corresponding to the list of start nodes for the BFS. This table must have a single column "node_id".

macros.name: graph_next_sibling
macros.desc:
Computes the next sibling node in a directed graph. The next node under a parent node
 is determined by on the |sort_key|, which should be unique for every node under a parent.
 The order of the next sibling is undefined if the |sort_key| is not unique.

 Example usage:
 ```
 -- Compute the next sibling:
 SELECT *
 FROM graph_next_sibling!(
   (
     SELECT
       id AS node_id,
       parent_id AS node_parent_id,
       ts AS sort_key
     FROM slice
   )
 );
 ```
macros.summary_desc: Computes the next sibling node in a directed graph
macros.return_desc: The returned table has the schema (node_id LONG, next_node_id LONG). |node_id| is the id of the node from the input graph and |next_node_id| is the id of the node which is its next sibling.

args.name: graph_table
args.desc: A table/view/subquery corresponding to a directed graph for which to find the next sibling. This table must have the columns "node_id", "node_parent_id" and "sort_key".

macros.name: graph_reachable_weight_bounded_dfs
macros.desc:
Computes the "reachable" set of nodes in a directed graph from a set of
 starting (root) nodes by performing a depth-first search from each root node on the graph.
 The search is bounded by the sum of edge weights on the path and the root node specifies the
 max weight (inclusive) allowed before stopping the search.
 The returned nodes are structured as a tree with parent-child relationships corresponding
 to the order in which nodes were encountered by the DFS. Each row also has the root node from
 which where the edge was encountered.

 While this macro can be used directly by end users (hence being public),
 it is primarily intended as a lower-level building block upon which higher
 level functions/macros in the standard library can be built.

 Example usage on traces with sched info:
 ```
 -- Compute the reachable nodes from a sched wakeup chain
 INCLUDE PERFETTO MODULE sched.thread_executing_spans;

 SELECT *
 FROM
   graph_reachable_dfs_bounded
    !(
      (
        SELECT
          id AS source_node_id,
          COALESCE(parent_id, id) AS dest_node_id,
          id - COALESCE(parent_id, id) AS edge_weight
        FROM _wakeup_chain
      ),
      (
        SELECT
          id AS root_node_id,
          id - COALESCE(prev_id, id) AS root_target_weight
        FROM _wakeup_chain
      ));
 ```
macros.summary_desc: Computes the "reachable" set of nodes in a directed graph from a set of  starting (root) nodes by performing a depth-first search from each root node on the graph
macros.return_desc: The returned table has the schema (root_node_id, node_id LONG, parent_node_id LONG). |root_node_id| is the id of the starting node under which this edge was encountered. |node_id| is the id of the node from the input graph and |parent_node_id| is the id of the node which was the first encountered predecessor in a DFS search of the graph.

args.name: graph_table
args.desc: A table/view/subquery corresponding to a directed graph on which the reachability search should be performed. This table must have the columns "source_node_id" and "dest_node_id" corresponding to the two nodes on either end of the edges in the graph and an "edge_weight" corresponding to the weight of the edge between the node.  Note: the columns must contain uint32 similar to ids in trace processor tables (i.e. the values should be relatively dense and close to zero). The implementation makes assumptions on this for performance reasons and, if this criteria is not, can lead to enormous amounts of memory being allocated.

args.name: root_table
args.desc: A table/view/subquery corresponding to start nodes to |graph_table| which will be the roots of the reachability trees. This table must have the columns "root_node_id" and "root_target_weight" corresponding to the starting node id and the max weight allowed on the tree.  Note: the columns must contain uint32 similar to ids in trace processor tables (i.e. the values should be relatively dense and close to zero). The implementation makes assumptions on this for performance reasons and, if this criteria is not, can lead to enormous amounts of memory being allocated.

args.name: is_target_weight_floor
args.desc: Whether the target_weight is a floor weight or ceiling weight. If it's floor, the search stops right after we exceed the target weight, and we include the node that pushed just passed the target. If ceiling, the search stops right before the target weight and the node that would have pushed us passed the target is not included.

macros.name: tree_structural_partition_by_group
macros.desc:
Partitions a tree into a forest of trees based on a given grouping key
 in a structure-preserving way.

 Specifically, for each tree in the output forest, all the nodes in that tree
 have the same ancestors and descendants as in the original tree *iff* that
 ancestor/descendent belonged to the same group.

 Example:
 Input

   id | parent_id | group_key
   ---|-----------|----------
   1  | NULL      | 1
   2  | 1         | 1
   3  | NULL      | 2
   4  | NULL      | 2
   5  | 2         | 1
   6  | NULL      | 3
   7  | 4         | 2
   8  | 4         | 1

 Or as a graph:
 ```
         1 (1)
        /
       2 (1)
      /  \
     3 (2) 4 (2)
           /   \
         5 (1) 8 (1)
        /  \
     6 (3) 7 (2)
 ```
 Possible output (order of rows is implementation-defined)

   id | parent_id | group_key
   ---|-----------|-------
   1  | NULL      | 1
   2  | 1         | 1
   3  | NULL      | 2
   4  | NULL      | 2
   5  | 2         | 1
   6  | NULL      | 3
   7  | 4         | 2
   8  | 2         | 1

 Or as a forest:
 ```
     1 (1)       3 (2)      4 (2)        6 (3)
      |                      |
     2 (1)                  7 (2)
     /   \
   5 (1) 8 (1)
 ```
macros.summary_desc: Partitions a tree into a forest of trees based on a given grouping key  in a structure-preserving way
macros.return_desc: The returned table has the schema (id LONG, parent_id LONG, group_key LONG).

args.name: tree_table
args.desc: A table/view/subquery corresponding to a tree which should be partitioned. This table must have the columns "id", "parent_id" and "group_key".  Note: the columns must contain uint32 similar to ids in trace processor tables (i.e. the values should be relatively dense and close to zero). The implementation makes assumptions on this for performance reasons and, if this criteria is not, can lead to enormous amounts of memory being allocated.

macros.name: graph_dominator_tree
macros.desc:
Given a table containing a directed flow-graph and an entry node, computes
 the "dominator tree" for the graph. See [1] for an explanation of what a
 dominator tree is.

 [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominator_(graph_theory)

 Example usage on traces containing heap graphs:
 ```
 CREATE PERFETTO VIEW dominator_compatible_heap_graph AS
 -- Extract the edges from the heap graph which correspond to references
 -- between objects.
 SELECT
   owner_id AS source_node_id,
   owned_id as dest_node_id
 FROM heap_graph_reference
 JOIN heap_graph_object owner on heap_graph_reference.owner_id = owner.id
 WHERE owned_id IS NOT NULL AND owner.reachable
 UNION ALL
 -- Since a Java heap graph is a "forest" structure, we need to add a dummy
 -- "root" node which connects all the roots of the forest into a single
 -- connected component.
 SELECT
   (SELECT max(id) + 1 FROM heap_graph_object) as source_node_id,
   id
 FROM heap_graph_object
 WHERE root_type IS NOT NULL;

 SELECT *
 FROM graph_dominator_tree!(
   dominator_compatible_heap_graph,
   (SELECT max(id) + 1 FROM heap_graph_object)
 );
 ```
macros.summary_desc: Given a table containing a directed flow-graph and an entry node, computes  the "dominator tree" for the graph
macros.return_desc: The returned table has the schema (node_id LONG, dominator_node_id LONG). |node_id| is the id of the node from the input graph and |dominator_node_id| is the id of the node in the input flow-graph which is the "dominator" of |node_id|.

args.name: graph_table
args.desc: A table/view/subquery corresponding to a directed flow-graph on which the dominator tree should be computed. This table must have the columns "source_node_id" and "dest_node_id" corresponding to the two nodes on either end of the edges in the graph.  Note: the columns must contain uint32 similar to ids in trace processor tables (i.e. the values should be relatively dense and close to zero). The implementation makes assumptions on this for performance reasons and, if this criteria is not, can lead to enormous amounts of memory being allocated.  Note: this means that the graph *must* be a single fully connected component with |root_node_id| (see below) being the "entry node" for this component. Specifically, all nodes *must* be reachable by following paths from the root node. Failing to adhere to this property will result in undefined behaviour.  If working with a "forest"-like structure, a dummy node should be added which links all the roots of the forest together into a single component; an example of this can be found in the heap graph example query above.

args.name: root_node_id
args.desc: The entry node to |graph_table| which will be the root of the dominator tree.

functions.name: android_standardize_thread_name
functions.desc:
Standardizes an Android thread name by extracting its core identifier to make it
 possible to aggregate by name.

 Removes extra parts of a thread name, like identifiers, leaving only the main prefix.
 Splits the name at ('-', '[', ':' , ' ').

 Some Examples:
   Given thread_name = "RenderThread-1[123]",
   returns "RenderThread".

   Given thread_name = "binder:5543_E"
   returns "binder".

   Given thread_name = "pool-3-thread-5",
   returns "pool".

   Given thread_name = "MainThread",
   returns "MainThread".
functions.summary_desc: Standardizes an Android thread name by extracting its core identifier to make it  possible to aggregate by name

args.name: thread_name
args.desc: The full android thread name to be processed.

data_objects.name: android_job_scheduler_events
data_objects.desc:
All scheduled jobs and their latencies.

 The table is populated by ATrace using the system server ATrace category
 (`atrace_categories: "ss"`). You can also set the `atrace_apps` of interest.

 This differs from the `android_job_scheduler_states` table
 in the `android.job_scheduler_states` module which is populated
 by the `ScheduledJobStateChanged` atom.

 Using `android_job_scheduler_states` is preferred when the
 `ATOM_SCHEDULED_JOB_STATE_CHANGED` is available in the trace since
 it includes the constraint, screen, or charging state changes for
 each job in a trace.

data_objects.name: android_input_events
data_objects.desc:
All input events with round trip latency breakdown. Input delivery is socket based and every
 input event sent from the OS needs to be ACK'ed by the app. This gives us 4 subevents to measure
 latencies between:
 1. Input dispatch event sent from OS.
 2. Input dispatch event received in app.
 3. Input ACK event sent from app.
 4. Input ACK event received in OS.
data_objects.summary_desc: All input events with round trip latency breakdown

data_objects.desc:
Aggregated thread_states on the client and server side per binder txn
 This builds on the data from |_sync_binder_metrics_by_txn| and
 for each end (client and server) of the transaction, it returns
 the aggregated sum of all the thread state durations.
 The |thread_state_type| column represents whether a given 'aggregated thread_state'
 row is on the client or server side. 'binder_txn' is client side and 'binder_reply'
 is server side.

table_functions.name: android_binder_outgoing_graph
table_functions.desc:
Returns a DAG of all outgoing binder txns from a process.
 The roots of the graph are the threads making the txns and the graph flows from:
 thread -> server_process -> AIDL interface -> AIDL method.
 The weights of each node represent the wall execution time in the server_process.
table_functions.summary_desc: Returns a DAG of all outgoing binder txns from a process

args.name: upid
args.desc: Upid of process to generate an outgoing graph for.

cols.name: pprof
cols.desc: Pprof of outgoing binder txns.

table_functions.name: android_binder_incoming_graph
table_functions.desc:
Returns a DAG of all incoming binder txns from a process.
 The roots of the graph are the clients making the txns and the graph flows from:
 client_process -> AIDL interface -> AIDL method.
 The weights of each node represent the wall execution time in the server_process.
table_functions.summary_desc: Returns a DAG of all incoming binder txns from a process

args.name: upid
args.desc: Upid of process to generate an incoming graph for.

cols.name: pprof
cols.desc: Pprof of incoming binder txns.

table_functions.name: android_binder_graph
table_functions.desc:
Returns a graph of all binder txns in a trace.
 The nodes are client_process and server_process.
 The weights of each node represent the wall execution time in the server_process.
table_functions.summary_desc: Returns a graph of all binder txns in a trace

args.name: min_client_oom_score
args.desc: Matches txns from client_processes greater than or equal to the OOM score.

args.name: max_client_oom_score
args.desc: Matches txns from client_processes less than or equal to the OOM score.

args.name: min_server_oom_score
args.desc: Matches txns to server_processes greater than or equal to the OOM score.

args.name: max_server_oom_score
args.desc: Matches txns to server_processes less than or equal to the OOM score.

cols.name: pprof
cols.desc: Pprof of binder txns.

modules.data_check_sql: SELECT EXISTS(SELECT 1 FROM slice WHERE name GLOB 'binder *' LIMIT 1) AS has_data

data_objects.name: android_monitor_contention_chain_thread_state
data_objects.desc:
Contains the span join of the first waiters in the |android_monitor_contention_chain| with their
 blocking_thread thread state.

 Note that we only span join the duration where the lock was actually held and contended.
 This can be less than the duration the lock was 'waited on' when a different waiter acquired the
 lock earlier than the first waiter.
data_objects.summary_desc: Contains the span join of the first waiters in the |android_monitor_contention_chain| with their  blocking_thread thread state

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Slice id of lock contention.

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: Timestamp of lock contention start.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: Wall clock duration of lock contention.

cols.name: blocking_utid
cols.desc: Utid of the blocking |thread_state|.

cols.name: blocked_function
cols.desc: Blocked kernel function of the blocking thread.

cols.name: state
cols.desc: Thread state of the blocking thread.

data_objects.name: android_monitor_contention_chain_thread_state_by_txn
data_objects.desc:
Aggregated thread_states on the 'blocking thread', the thread holding the lock.
 This builds on the data from |android_monitor_contention_chain| and
 for each contention slice, it returns the aggregated sum of all the thread states on the
 blocking thread.

 Note that this data is only available for the first waiter on a lock.
data_objects.summary_desc: Aggregated thread_states on the 'blocking thread', the thread holding the lock

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Slice id of the monitor contention.

cols.name: thread_state
cols.desc: A |thread_state| that occurred in the blocking thread during the contention.

cols.name: thread_state_dur
cols.desc: Total time the blocking thread spent in the |thread_state| during contention.

cols.name: thread_state_count
cols.desc: Count of all times the blocking thread entered |thread_state| during the contention.

data_objects.name: android_monitor_contention_chain_blocked_functions_by_txn
data_objects.desc:
Aggregated blocked_functions on the 'blocking thread', the thread holding the lock.
 This builds on the data from |android_monitor_contention_chain| and
 for each contention, it returns the aggregated sum of all the kernel
 blocked function durations on the blocking thread.

 Note that this data is only available for the first waiter on a lock.
data_objects.summary_desc: Aggregated blocked_functions on the 'blocking thread', the thread holding the lock

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Slice id of the monitor contention.

cols.name: blocked_function
cols.desc: Blocked kernel function in a thread state in the blocking thread during the contention.

cols.name: blocked_function_dur
cols.desc: Total time the blocking thread spent in the |blocked_function| during the contention.

cols.name: blocked_function_count
cols.desc: Count of all times the blocking thread executed the |blocked_function| during the contention.

table_functions.name: android_monitor_contention_graph
table_functions.desc:
Returns a DAG of all Java lock contentions in a process.
 Each node in the graph is a <thread:Java method> pair.
 Each edge connects from a node waiting on a lock to a node holding a lock.
 The weights of each node represent the cumulative wall time the node blocked
 other nodes connected to it.
table_functions.summary_desc: Returns a DAG of all Java lock contentions in a process

args.name: upid
args.desc: Upid of process to generate a lock graph for.

cols.name: pprof
cols.desc: Pprof of lock graph.

functions.name: android_standardize_slice_name
functions.desc:
Some slice names have params in them. This functions removes them to make it
 possible to aggregate by name.
 Some examples are:
  - Lock/monitor contention slices. The name includes where the lock
    contention is in the code. That part is removed.
  - DrawFrames/ooFrame. The name also includes the frame number.
  - Apk/oat/dex loading: The name of the apk is removed
functions.summary_desc: Some slice names have params in them

data_objects.name: android_user_list
data_objects.desc:
Contains information about Android users in the trace.

 This is populated by the `android.user_list` data-source which lives in
 traced_probes and is available on default from 26Q2+ devices.

 Note: `users` here corresponds to Android users *not* Linux users. So
 this is not about Linux uids (which in Android correspons to different
 apps).
data_objects.summary_desc: Contains information about Android users in the trace

cols.name: android_user_id
cols.desc: The Android user id.  Often useful to join with `android_process_metadata.user_id`

cols.name: type
cols.desc: A string "enum" indicating the type of the user according to the system.  Will be one for a few constant values e.g. HEADLESS, SECONDARY, GUEST.

modules.data_check_sql: SELECT EXISTS(SELECT 1 FROM __intrinsic_android_user_list LIMIT 1) AS has_data

data_objects.name: android_wakeups
data_objects.desc:
Table of parsed wakeup / suspend failure events with suspend backoff.

 Certain wakeup events may have multiple causes. When this occurs we
 split those causes into multiple rows in this table with the same ts
 and raw_wakeup values.
data_objects.summary_desc: Table of parsed wakeup / suspend failure events with suspend backoff

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: Timestamp.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: Duration for which we blame the wakeup for wakefulness. This is the suspend backoff duration if one exists, or the lesser of (5 seconds, time to next suspend event).

cols.name: raw_wakeup
cols.desc: Original wakeup string from the kernel.

cols.name: on_device_attribution
cols.desc: Wakeup attribution, as determined on device. May be absent.

cols.name: type
cols.desc: One of 'normal' (device woke from sleep), 'abort_pending' (suspend failed due to a wakeup that was scheduled by a device during the suspend process), 'abort_last_active' (suspend failed, listing the last active device) or 'abort_other' (suspend failed for another reason).

cols.name: item
cols.desc: Individual wakeup cause. Usually the name of the device that cause the wakeup, or the raw message in the 'abort_other' case.

cols.name: suspend_quality
cols.desc: 'good' or 'bad'. 'bad' means failed or short such that suspend backoff is triggered.

cols.name: backoff_state
cols.desc: 'new', 'continue' or NULL. Set if suspend backoff is triggered.

cols.name: backoff_reason
cols.desc: 'short', 'failed' or NULL. Set if suspend backoff is triggered.

cols.name: backoff_count
cols.desc: Number of times suspend backoff has occurred, or NULL. Set if suspend backoff is triggered.

cols.name: backoff_millis
cols.desc: Next suspend backoff duration, or NULL. Set if suspend backoff is triggered.

modules.data_check_sql: SELECT EXISTS(SELECT 1 FROM track WHERE name = 'wakeup_reason' LIMIT 1) AS has_data
