data_objects.name: android_statsd_atoms
data_objects.desc:
Statsd atoms.

 A subset of the slice table containing statsd atom instant events.
data_objects.summary_desc: Statsd atoms

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Unique identifier for this slice.

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: The timestamp at the start of the slice.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: The duration of the slice.

cols.name: arg_set_id
cols.desc: The id of the argument set associated with this slice.

cols.name: thread_instruction_count
cols.desc: The value of the CPU instruction counter at the start of the slice. This column will only be populated if thread instruction collection is enabled with track_event.

cols.name: thread_instruction_delta
cols.desc: The change in value of the CPU instruction counter between the start and end of the slice. This column will only be populated if thread instruction collection is enabled with track_event.

cols.name: track_id
cols.desc: The id of the track this slice is located on.

cols.name: category
cols.desc: The "category" of the slice. If this slice originated with track_event, this column contains the category emitted. Otherwise, it is likely to be null (with limited exceptions).

cols.name: name
cols.desc: The name of the slice. The name describes what was happening during the slice.

cols.name: depth
cols.desc: The depth of the slice in the current stack of slices.

cols.name: parent_id
cols.desc: The id of the parent (i.e. immediate ancestor) slice for this slice.

cols.name: thread_ts
cols.desc: The thread timestamp at the start of the slice. This column will only be populated if thread timestamp collection is enabled with track_event.

cols.name: thread_dur
cols.desc: The thread time used by this slice. This column will only be populated if thread timestamp collection is enabled with track_event.

modules.data_check_sql: SELECT EXISTS(SELECT 1 FROM track WHERE name = 'Statsd Atoms' LIMIT 1) AS has_data

macros.name: android_network_uptime_spans
macros.desc:
Computes network uptime spans based on an idle timeout model.

 It is common in networking to have an interface active for some time after
 use. For example, mobile networks are often connected for 10 or more seconds
 after the last packet is sent or received. This macro simulates this timeout
 and returns spans that approximate the underlying connected regions.
macros.summary_desc: Computes network uptime spans based on an idle timeout model

args.name: src
args.desc: A table/view/subquery containing the network events to apply the idle timeout model to. The table must contain all partition_columns, ts, dur, packet_count, and packet_length.

args.name: partition_columns
args.desc: A parenthesized set of columns to partition the analysis by.

args.name: timeout
args.desc: The idle timeout, expressed in nanoseconds.

macros.name: android_network_uptime_cost
macros.desc:
Compute the per-row uptime cost of network activity.

 It is common in networking to have an interface active for some time after
 use. For example, mobile networks are often connected for 10 or more seconds
 after the last packet is sent or received. This macro computes a cost factor
 indicating how much each row impacts the idle timer.

 For example, assuming a 10s timeout, the first packet will extend the timeout
 10s in the future, and be assigned 10s of cost. If a packet arrives 4s later,
 it pushes the timer an additional 4s, receiving 4s of cost. In this simple
 case, cost is MIN(ts-last_packet_ts, timeout).

 The complication is that network events can be aggregates, with more than one
 packet. In such cases, we end up with a span with non-zero duration, rather
 than an instant, and no easy way to compute time since the last packet.

 The solution is to detect overlap regions and compute cost for the region as
 a whole. The first event in each group receives the standard uptime cost as
 described above. Each group has an additional cost equal to the duration of
 the group which is distributed using packet count as weight.

 For example (times in seconds, no partition, and 10 second timeout):
 ```
 ts=5,  dur=0, packet_count=1  -> group=1, uptime_cost=10
 ts=7,  dur=0, packet_count=1  -> group=2, uptime_cost=2
 ts=20, dur=5, packet_count=9  -> group=3, uptime_cost=14.5
 ts=22, dur=0, packet_count=1  -> group=3, uptime_cost=0.5
 ```
 The third group spans ts=20 to ts=25, with a timeout at ts=35. This gives the
 group a total cost of 15 which is distributed between the two rows. The 3rd
 row receives 10s for being first, and 9/10 the duration cost (5*9/10=4.5).

 The returned table schema is (id ID, uptime_cost INT64) where uptime cost is
 in nanoseconds.
macros.summary_desc: Compute the per-row uptime cost of network activity

args.name: src
args.desc: A table/view/subquery containing the network events to apply the idle timeout model to. The table must contain all partition_columns, id, ts, dur, and packet_count.

args.name: partition_columns
args.desc: A parenthesized set of columns to partition the analysis by.

args.name: timeout
args.desc: The idle timeout, expressed in nanoseconds.

modules.data_check_sql: SELECT EXISTS(SELECT 1 FROM __intrinsic_android_network_packets LIMIT 1) AS has_data

data_objects.name: android_battery_stats_event_slices
data_objects.desc:
View of slices derived from battery_stats events. Battery stats records all
 events as instants, however some may indicate whether something started or
 stopped with a '+' or '-' prefix. Events such as jobs, top apps, foreground
 apps or long wakes include these details and allow drawing slices between
 instant events found in a trace.

 For example, we may see an event like the following on 'battery_stats.top':

     -top=10215:"com.google.android.apps.nexuslauncher"

 This view will find the associated start ('+top') with the matching suffix
 (everything after the '=') to construct a slice. It computes the timestamp
 and duration from the events and extract the details as follows:

     track_name='battery_stats.top'
     str_value='com.google.android.apps.nexuslauncher'
     int_value=10215
data_objects.summary_desc: View of slices derived from battery_stats events

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: Start of a new battery state.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: The duration the state was active, -1 for incomplete slices.

cols.name: safe_dur
cols.desc: The same as `dur`, but extends to trace end for incomplete slices.

cols.name: track_name
cols.desc: The name of the counter track.

cols.name: str_value
cols.desc: String value.

cols.name: int_value
cols.desc: Int value.

functions.desc: Converts a battery_stats counter value to human readable string.

 (`android.job_scheduler_states`) by only having job constraint information.

 for how tables in this module differ from `android_job_scheduler_events`

data_objects.name: android_job_scheduler_with_screen_charging_states
data_objects.desc:
This table returns the constraint, charging,
 and screen state changes that a job will go through
 in a single trace.

 Values from this table are derived from
 the `ScheduledJobStateChanged` atom. This differs from the
 `android_job_scheduler_events` table in the `android.job_scheduler` module
 which is derived from ATrace the system server category
 (`atrace_categories: "ss"`).

 This also differs from the `android_job_scheduler_states` in this module
 (`android.job_scheduler_states`) by providing charging and screen state
 changes.

 To populate this table, enable the Statsd Tracing Config with the
 ATOM_SCHEDULED_JOB_STATE_CHANGED push atom id.
 https://perfetto.dev/docs/reference/trace-config-proto#StatsdTracingConfig

 This table is preferred over `android_job_scheduler_events`
 since it contains more information and should be used whenever
 `ATOM_SCHEDULED_JOB_STATE_CHANGED` is available in a trace.

data_objects.name: android_sysui_jank_cujs
data_objects.desc: Table tracking all jank CUJs information.
data_objects.summary_desc: Table tracking all jank CUJs information

cols.name: cuj_id
cols.desc: Unique incremental ID for each CUJ.

cols.name: upid
cols.desc: process id.

cols.name: process_name
cols.desc: process name.

cols.name: cuj_slice_name
cols.desc: Name of the CUJ slice.

cols.name: cuj_name
cols.desc: Name of the CUJ without the 'J<' prefix.

cols.name: slice_id
cols.desc: Id of the CUJ slice in perfetto. Keeping the slice id column as part of this table as provision to lookup the actual CUJ slice ts and dur. The ts and dur in this table might differ from the slice duration, as they are associated with start and end frame corresponding to the CUJ.

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: Start timestamp of the CUJ. Start of the CUJ as defined by the start of the first overlapping expected frame.

cols.name: ts_end
cols.desc: End timestamp of the CUJ. Calculated as the end timestamp of the last actual frame overlapping with the CUJ.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: Duration of the CUJ calculated based on the ts and ts_end values.

cols.name: state
cols.desc: State of the CUJ. One of "completed", "cancelled" or NULL. NULL in cases where the FT#cancel or FT#end instant event is not present for the CUJ.

cols.name: ui_thread
cols.desc: thread id of the UI thread.

cols.name: layer_id
cols.desc: layer id associated with the actual frame.

cols.name: begin_vsync
cols.desc: vysnc id of the first frame that falls within the CUJ boundary.

cols.name: end_vsync
cols.desc: vysnc id of the last frame that falls within the CUJ boundary.

data_objects.name: android_heap_profile_summary_tree
data_objects.desc:
Table summarising the amount of memory allocated by each
 callstack as seen by Android native heap profiling (i.e.
 profiling information collected by heapprofd).

 Note: this table collapses data from all processes together
 into a single table.
data_objects.summary_desc: Table summarising the amount of memory allocated by each  callstack as seen by Android native heap profiling (i.e

cols.name: id
cols.desc: The id of the callstack. A callstack in this context is a unique set of frames up to the root.

cols.name: parent_id
cols.desc: The id of the parent callstack for this callstack.

cols.name: name
cols.desc: The function name of the frame for this callstack.

cols.name: mapping_name
cols.desc: The name of the mapping containing the frame. This can be a native binary, library, JAR or APK.

cols.name: source_file
cols.desc: The name of the file containing the function.

cols.name: line_number
cols.desc: The line number in the file the function is located at.

cols.name: self_size
cols.desc: The amount of memory allocated and *not freed* with this function as the leaf frame.

cols.name: cumulative_size
cols.desc: The amount of memory allocated and *not freed* with this function appearing anywhere on the callstack.

cols.name: self_alloc_size
cols.desc: The amount of memory allocated with this function as the leaf frame. This may include memory which was later freed.

cols.name: cumulative_alloc_size
cols.desc: The amount of memory allocated with this function appearing anywhere on the callstack. This may include memory which was later freed.

macros.name: android_heap_graph_class_find_descendants
macros.desc:
Given a list of classes as ancestor classes, return all the classes that
 descend from them.
macros.summary_desc: Given a list of classes as ancestor classes, return all the classes that  descend from them
macros.return_desc: Table of the schema (id JOINID(heap_graph_class.id), ancestor_class_id JOINID(heap_graph_class.id), ancestor_class_name STRING) id: `id` of the class as in heap_graph_class ancestor_class_id: `id` of the ancestor class as given in the input ancestor_class_name: `name` of the ancestor class as in heap_graph_class

args.name: ancestor_class_ids
args.desc: ancestor class `id`s from the heap_graph_class table containing a single column: `id`

data_objects.name: android_heap_graph_class_summary_tree
data_objects.desc:
Table containing all the Android heap graphs in the trace converted to a
 shortest-path tree and then aggregated by class name.

 This table contains a "flamegraph-like" representation of the contents of the
 heap graph.
data_objects.summary_desc: Table containing all the Android heap graphs in the trace converted to a  shortest-path tree and then aggregated by class name

cols.name: graph_sample_ts
cols.desc: The timestamp the heap graph was dumped at.

cols.name: upid
cols.desc: The upid of the process.

cols.name: id
cols.desc: The id of the node in the class tree.

cols.name: parent_id
cols.desc: The parent id of the node in the class tree or NULL if this is the root.

cols.name: name
cols.desc: The name of the class.

cols.name: root_type
cols.desc: A string describing the type of Java root if this node is a root or NULL if this node is not a root.

cols.name: self_count
cols.desc: The count of objects with the same class name and the same path to the root.

cols.name: self_size
cols.desc: The size of objects with the same class name and the same path to the root.

cols.name: cumulative_count
cols.desc: The sum of `self_count` of this node and all descendants of this node.

cols.name: cumulative_size
cols.desc: The sum of `self_size` of this node and all descendants of this node.

data_objects.name: heap_graph_dominator_tree
data_objects.desc:
All reachable heap graph objects, their immediate dominators and summary of
 their dominated sets.
 The heap graph dominator tree is calculated by stdlib graphs.dominator_tree.
 Each reachable object is a node in the dominator tree, their immediate
 dominator is their parent node in the tree, and their dominated set is all
 their descendants in the tree. All size information come from the
 heap_graph_object prelude table.
data_objects.summary_desc: All reachable heap graph objects, their immediate dominators and summary of  their dominated sets

cols.name: id
cols.desc: Heap graph object id.

cols.name: idom_id
cols.desc: Immediate dominator object id of the object. If the immediate dominator is the "super-root" (i.e. the object is a root or is dominated by multiple roots) then `idom_id` will be NULL.

cols.name: dominated_obj_count
cols.desc: Count of all objects dominated by this object, self inclusive.

cols.name: dominated_size_bytes
cols.desc: Total self_size of all objects dominated by this object, self inclusive.

cols.name: dominated_native_size_bytes
cols.desc: Total native_size of all objects dominated by this object, self inclusive.

cols.name: depth
cols.desc: Depth of the object in the dominator tree. Depth of root objects are 1.

data_objects.name: android_heap_graph_stats
data_objects.desc:
Table summarizing java heap graphs collected with the ART perfetto module.
 Contains one row per heap graph, with summary statistics (e.g. total / reachable objects)
 and memory stats for the corresponding process at the time of the heap dump.
data_objects.summary_desc: Table summarizing java heap graphs collected with the ART perfetto module

cols.name: upid
cols.desc: The upid of the process.

cols.name: graph_sample_ts
cols.desc: The timestamp the heap graph was dumped at.

cols.name: process_uptime
cols.desc: The uptime of the process at the time of the heap graph dump.

cols.name: total_heap_size
cols.desc: The total (reachable + unreachable) size of the Java heap in bytes.

cols.name: total_native_alloc_registry_size
cols.desc: The total size of native allocations (registered with NativeAllocationRegistry) in bytes. Does *not* overlap with total_heap_size.

cols.name: total_obj_count
cols.desc: The number of objects in the heap.

cols.name: reachable_heap_size
cols.desc: The reachable size of the Java heap in bytes.

cols.name: reachable_native_alloc_registry_size
cols.desc: The size of reachable native allocations (registered with NativeAllocationRegistry) in bytes.

cols.name: reachable_obj_count
cols.desc: The number of reachable objects in the heap.

cols.name: oom_score_adj
cols.desc: The OOM score adj of the process at the time of the heap graph dump.

cols.name: anon_rss_and_swap_size
cols.desc: The anon RSS + swap size of the process (in bytes) at the time of the heap graph dump.

cols.name: dmabuf_rss_size
cols.desc: The dmabuf size of the process (in bytes) at the time of the heap graph dump.

data_objects.name: android_heap_graph_class_aggregation
data_objects.desc:
Class-level breakdown of the java heap.
 Per type name aggregates the object stats and the dominator tree stats.
data_objects.summary_desc: Class-level breakdown of the java heap

cols.name: upid
cols.desc: Process upid

cols.name: graph_sample_ts
cols.desc: Heap dump timestamp

cols.name: type_id
cols.desc: Class type id

cols.name: type_name
cols.desc: Class name (deobfuscated if available)

cols.name: is_libcore_or_array
cols.desc: Is type an instance of a libcore object (java.*) or array

cols.name: obj_count
cols.desc: Count of class instances

cols.name: size_bytes
cols.desc: Size of class instances

cols.name: native_size_bytes
cols.desc: Native size of class instances

cols.name: reachable_obj_count
cols.desc: Count of reachable class instances

cols.name: reachable_size_bytes
cols.desc: Size of reachable class instances

cols.name: reachable_native_size_bytes
cols.desc: Native size of reachable class instances

cols.name: dominated_obj_count
cols.desc: Count of all objects dominated by instances of this class Only applies to reachable objects

cols.name: dominated_size_bytes
cols.desc: Size of all objects dominated by instances of this class Only applies to reachable objects

cols.name: dominated_native_size_bytes
cols.desc: Native size of all objects dominated by instances of this class Only applies to reachable objects

data_objects.name: android_profiling_manager_cold_startup
data_objects.desc:
Provides cold startups for redacted traces
 Note: Redacted traces contain a subset of slices compare to a regular perfetto trace as they contain information only about the process
 starting its own profiling, thus, queries in this section may omit process information as its assumed that slices belong
 to the single profiled process.
data_objects.summary_desc: Provides cold startups for redacted traces  Note: Redacted traces contain a subset of slices compare to a regular perfetto trace as they contain information only about the process  starting its own profiling, thus, queries in this section may omit process information as its assumed that slices belong  to the single profiled process

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: Initial timestamp for startup from apps perspective

cols.name: name
cols.desc: slice name to identify the startup

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: duration in nanoseconds

cols.name: startup_checkpoint
cols.desc: Checkpoint where startup is marked as finished. Two cases: TTFF (Time to first frame): Startup marked as finished after first frame done TTI (Time to interactive): Startup marked as finished after app calls Activity#reportFullyDrawn()

data_objects.name: android_cpu_per_uid_track
data_objects.desc:
Table of tracks for CPU-per-UID data. Each row represents one UID / cluster
 combination.
data_objects.summary_desc: Table of tracks for CPU-per-UID data

cols.name: id
cols.desc: ID of the track; can be joined with cpu_per_uid_counter.

cols.name: uid
cols.desc: UID doing the work.

cols.name: cluster
cols.desc: Cluster ID for the track, starting from 0, typically with larger numbers meaning larger cores.

cols.name: total_cpu_millis
cols.desc: Total number of cpu millis used by this track.

cols.name: package_name
cols.desc: A package name for the UID. If there are multiple for a UID, one is chosen arbitrarily. UIDs below 10000 always have null package name.

data_objects.name: android_cpu_per_uid_counter
data_objects.desc:
View of counters for CPU-per-UID data. Each row represents one instant in
 time for one UID / cluster.
data_objects.summary_desc: View of counters for CPU-per-UID data

cols.name: id
cols.desc: ID for the row.

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: Timestamp for the row.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: Time to the next measurement for the UID / cluster combination.

cols.name: track_id
cols.desc: Associated track.

cols.name: diff_ms
cols.desc: CPU time measurement for this time period (milliseconds).

cols.name: cpu_ratio
cols.desc: Inferred CPU use value for the period where 1.0 means a single core at 100% utilisation.

modules.data_check_sql: SELECT EXISTS(SELECT 1 FROM __intrinsic_android_cpu_per_uid_track LIMIT 1) AS has_data

data_objects.name: android_cpu_cluster_mapping
data_objects.desc:
Stores the mapping of a cpu to its cluster type - e.g. little, medium, big.
 This cluster type is determined by initially using cpu_capacity from sysfs
 and grouping clusters with identical capacities, ordered by size.
 In the case that capacities are not present, max frequency is used instead.
 If nothing is avaiable, NULL is returned.
data_objects.summary_desc: Stores the mapping of a cpu to its cluster type - e.g

cols.name: ucpu
cols.desc: Alias of `cpu.ucpu`.

cols.name: cpu
cols.desc: Alias of `cpu.cpu`.

cols.name: cluster_type
cols.desc: The cluster type of the CPU.

All of the `DrawFrame` slices with their frame id and render thread.

data_objects.name: android_frames_layers
data_objects.desc:
TODO(b/384322064) Match actual timeline slice with correct draw frame using layer name.
 All slices related to one frame. Aggregates `Choreographer#doFrame`,
 `actual_frame_timeline_slice` and `expected_frame_timeline_slice` slices.
 This table differs slightly from the android_frames table, as it
 captures the layer_id for each actual timeline slice too.
data_objects.summary_desc: TODO(b/384322064) Match actual timeline slice with correct draw frame using layer name

cols.name: frame_id
cols.desc: Frame id.

cols.desc: Timestamp of the frame. Start of the frame as defined by the start of "Choreographer#doFrame" slice and the same as the start of the frame in `actual_frame_timeline_slice if present.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: Duration of the frame, as defined by the duration of the corresponding `actual_frame_timeline_slice` or, if not present the time between the `ts` and the end of the final `DrawFrame`.

cols.name: ts_end
cols.desc: End timestamp of the frame. End of the frame as defined by the sum of start timestamp and duration of the frame.

cols.name: do_frame_id
cols.desc: `slice.id` of "Choreographer#doFrame" slice.

cols.name: draw_frame_id
cols.desc: `slice.id` of "DrawFrame" slice. For now, we only support the first DrawFrame slice (due to b/384322064).

cols.name: expected_frame_timeline_id

cols.name: render_thread_utid

cols.desc: thread id of the UI thread.

cols.name: layer_id
cols.desc: layer id associated with the actual frame.

cols.name: layer_name
cols.desc: layer name associated with the actual frame.

cols.name: upid
cols.desc: process id.

cols.name: process_name
cols.desc: process name.

modules.data_check_sql: SELECT EXISTS(SELECT 1 FROM slice WHERE name GLOB 'Choreographer#doFrame*' OR name GLOB 'DrawFrame*' LIMIT 1) AS has_data

data_objects.name: android_frames_overrun
data_objects.desc:
The amount by which each frame missed of hit its deadline. Negative if the
 deadline was not missed. Frames are considered janky if `overrun` is
 positive.
 Calculated as the difference between the end of the
 `expected_frame_timeline_slice` and `actual_frame_timeline_slice` for the
 frame.
 Availability: from S (API 31).
 For Googlers: more details in go/android-performance-metrics-glossary.
data_objects.summary_desc: The amount by which each frame missed of hit its deadline

cols.name: frame_id
cols.desc: Frame id.

cols.name: overrun
cols.desc: Difference between `expected` and `actual` frame ends. Negative if frame didn't miss deadline.

data_objects.name: android_frames_ui_time
data_objects.desc: How much time did the frame's Choreographer callbacks take.
data_objects.summary_desc: How much time did the frame's Choreographer callbacks take

cols.name: frame_id
cols.desc: Frame id

cols.name: ui_time
cols.desc: UI time duration

data_objects.name: android_app_vsync_delay_per_frame
data_objects.desc:
App Vsync delay for a frame. The time between the VSYNC-app signal and the
 start of Choreographer work.
 Calculated as time difference between the actual frame start (from
 `actual_frame_timeline_slice`) and start of the `Choreographer#doFrame`
 slice.
 For Googlers: more details in go/android-performance-metrics-glossary.
data_objects.summary_desc: App Vsync delay for a frame

cols.name: frame_id
cols.desc: Frame id

cols.name: app_vsync_delay
cols.desc: App VSYNC delay.

data_objects.name: android_cpu_time_per_frame
data_objects.desc:
How much time did the frame take across the UI Thread + RenderThread.
 Calculated as sum of `app VSYNC delay` `Choreographer#doFrame` slice
 duration and summed durations of all `DrawFrame` slices associated with this
 frame.
 Availability: from N (API 24).
 For Googlers: more details in go/android-performance-metrics-glossary.
data_objects.summary_desc: How much time did the frame take across the UI Thread + RenderThread

cols.name: frame_id
cols.desc: Frame id

cols.name: app_vsync_delay
cols.desc: Difference between actual timeline of the frame and `Choreographer#doFrame`. See `android_app_vsync_delay_per_frame` table for more details.

cols.name: do_frame_dur
cols.desc: Duration of `Choreographer#doFrame` slice.

cols.name: draw_frame_dur
cols.desc: Duration of `DrawFrame` slice. Summed duration of all `DrawFrame` slices, if more than one. See `android_frames_draw_frame` for more details.

cols.name: cpu_time
cols.desc: CPU time across the UI Thread + RenderThread.

data_objects.name: android_startup_time_to_display
data_objects.desc:
Startup metric defintions, which focus on the observable time range:
 TTID - Time To Initial Display
 * https://developer.android.com/topic/performance/vitals/launch-time#time-initial
 * end of first RenderThread.DrawFrame - bindApplication
 TTFD - Time To Full Display
 * https://developer.android.com/topic/performance/vitals/launch-time#retrieve-TTFD
 * end of next RT.DrawFrame, after reportFullyDrawn called - bindApplication
 Googlers: see go/android-performance-metrics-glossary for details.
data_objects.summary_desc: Startup metric defintions, which focus on the observable time range:  TTID - Time To Initial Display  * https://developer

cols.name: startup_id
cols.desc: Startup id.

cols.desc: Time to initial display (TTID)

cols.name: time_to_full_display
cols.desc: Time to full display (TTFD)

cols.desc: `android_frames.frame_id` of frame for initial display

cols.name: ttfd_frame_id
cols.desc: `android_frames.frame_id` of frame for full display

cols.name: upid
cols.desc: `process.upid` of the startup

data_objects.name: android_startup_opinionated_breakdown
data_objects.desc:
Blended thread state and slice breakdown blocking app startups.

 Each row blames a unique period during an app startup with a reason
 derived from the slices and thread states on the main thread.

 Some helpful events to enables are binder transactions, ART, am and view.
data_objects.summary_desc: Blended thread state and slice breakdown blocking app startups

cols.name: startup_id
cols.desc: Startup id.

cols.name: slice_id
cols.desc: Id of relevant slice blocking startup.

cols.name: thread_state_id
cols.desc: Id of thread_state blocking startup.

cols.name: ts
cols.desc: Timestamp of an exclusive interval during the app startup with a single latency reason.

cols.name: dur
cols.desc: Duration of an exclusive interval during the app startup with a single latency reason.

cols.name: reason
cols.desc: Cause of delay during an exclusive interval of the app startup.
